response.answer_text: As the name suggests, this type of essay focuses on you as a person. You may want to talk about something that happened in your life that changed your thinking (or behavior!), some characteristics of your family of which you’re particularly proud, something you’re particularly passionate about (a subject at school, a specific type of athletics, drawing/singing/dancing/etc.), or something about your friendships (a particularly close friend or your group of buddies). Whatever subject you choose, remember that you are the central character in your essay. The reader should come away with a sense of who you are. To accomplish this, you’ll probably want to use the “narrative essay” style. Once you have your ideas sketched out in rough paragraphs, you’ll want to edit each sentence and paragraph to be sure that the word-picture you’re “painting” is vivid to the reader— descriptive action verbs, specific details of events, situations, and people. You want the reader to be able to see what you saw, feel what you felt. Remember, though: Everything you write must be factual. No embellishments, nothing invented to make it more interesting than the facts support.

A personal essay is one in which the author presents his/her own personal opinion. The topic would be up to the writer unless a teacher made a specific assignment concerning, say, your views on television violence.
